segments.text: I am delighted to announce that Intel is
back. Their brand new Ultra X9 CPU, it
does live up to the hype. It is as
powerful as Arrol Lake H. That's the
chip that was found in high performance
laptops last year like Asus's famous
Sephus G16
and it's able to do this at Luna Lake
power draws, which was the chip found in
thinner light laptops that gave you
excellent battery life. This means you
can finally have it all. Strong CPU
performance and long battery life in an
x86 Windows laptop. But there's more.
This new integrated GPU is absolutely
fantastic. Performance that rivals
entry-level GPUs from Nvidia, at least
at lower wattage. And because this
processor is so power efficient, you can
get all this performance in a super thin
and light laptop that is silent and
doesn't get that warm. Guys, the team
has just worked super hard on today's
video. Seriously, three people working
round the clock testing a ton of
laptops. I don't want to steal their
thunder, so I'm going to hand over to
Sierra to walk you through Panther Lake
and specifically how this new Core Ultra
X9 chip performs. I'll be back at the
end, though, to wrap up on how it stacks
up versus competitors and whether you
should actually buy one. Intel released
a whopping 14 CPUs, so there's a lot to
sort through. In summary, there are
three main types for three different
types of users. First, we have the Core
Ultra X7 and X9 processors that end with
H. Those are your highest tier options,
best for people looking for performance
and who also want some performance in
gaming and creative tasks. These have 16
core CPUs and a special 12 core GPU
called ARC B390. Next, we have the rest
of the CPUs that end in H. These still
have higher core count CPUs like the
prior ones, but they only have a 4 core
GPU. These are best suited for users
like programmers, audio engineers, and
even some students, all of whom don't
plan to be gaming or creating on the
side. Both these types of processors are
a direct replacement of last year's
Aerolake Hline. The Core Ultra Series 2
chips, which also had an H at the end.
These offered solid performance, but
usually mediocre battery life, the
latter of which series 3 does improve
on. Lastly, we have the lower core count
CPUs. These will not have a letter at
the end of the name and will be best for
folks who stick to simple stuff like web
browsing, office work, and studying.
They are a replacement for late 2024's
Lunar Lake. You may know these as the
series 2 chips that ended in V. They
offered great battery life, but mediocre
performance. Now that the basics are out
of the way, I'm going to go over a
couple gotchas to be aware of. As
always, Intel just couldn't keep it
simple. biggest thing is the fact that
not all Core Ultra 7s will perform
better than a Core Ultra 5. There are
nonH7s and there are fives that end in
H. That letter at the end will help you
determine performance better than the
number at the beginning. Secondly, there
are many Ultra 5 chips. Two have 12
cores and at the other end of the scale,
two have six. So, be careful which Ultra
5 you buy. Another thing, there is a
third GPU option in one of the Ultra 5H
chips. The Ultra 5 338HH seems to be a
slightly cut down version of the X7 and
X9 chips. It has a 10 core GPU instead
of a 12-core one. We think this chip has
the potential to offer really strong
price for performance, so we're excited
to get it in. As Josh mentioned in his
outrage video, Intel's naming sucks.
We're really confused why this one
doesn't also start with X like the other
three, plus all the other issues I
already brought up. All right, I've kept
you waiting long enough. In Geekbench,
the X9 chip performs well in multi-core.
It lands between the AeroLake H chips of
last gen in the Idea Pad and the LG
Graham Pro. It does better than AMD's
Ryzen 9 chip in the Omnibook and
Qualcomm Snapdragon chip in the Slim 7X
as well. The MacBook Pro with the M4 Pro
chip and the Flowzy 13 with stricks Halo
have a very solid lead here. These are
also laptops with powerful CPUs and
great integrated graphics. The MacBooks
also maintain a very large lead in terms
of single core score in all our graphs.
The reason we're comparing to expensive
devices like the Max is because the X9
is the highest end chip. We expect it to
be found in laptops ranging from mid000s
to mid2000s. We'd love to be wrong if
it's cheaper, though. This is just how
we decided which laptops to show. Now,
on to Cinebench, which tests max
performance. We're currently
transitioning between Cinebench 24 and
26 since it just came out. So, some of
our graphs will be using the older 24
version until we're completely done with
the transition. In 24, the Duo keeps up
with the M5 MacBook Pro in multi-core.
It beats laptops with last gen chips,
landing near the top of the graph, still
lagging behind the M4 Pro Mac and the
Flow with the Stricks Halo chip, aka AI
Max 395. In 26 Cinebench, they renamed
the tests to be more accurate as single
and multi-thread. Here in single thread
performance, we actually see a lift over
last generation from the X9 388H instead
of their tie in 2024. About an 8%
improvement here. Clearly 26 Cinebench
has some new optimizations for newer
processors. Unsurprisingly, the Max keep
their lead in 26 multi-threaded
performance. It's a similar story to the
other graphs. The X9 maintains great
Aerolake H performance while still
falling behind our two highest end chips
on the graph. Now, what this performance
doesn't show you is efficiency, which
this new chip does quite well. In case
you haven't seen this graph before on
our channel, we plot Cinebench
performance on the Y-axis and average
power draw along the X. Lower power draw
and higher performance is the goal here.
This is important because in a laptop,
more power consumption can make the
laptop feel warmer, have louder fan
noise, and shorter battery life. Unlike
last gen, Intel is now ahead of AMD's
Ryzen 9 HX370 stricks point chip. It
delivers slightly better performance at
similar power draws. We only just got a
laptop with AMD's 2026 Gorgon point in
and this Panther Lake X9 CPU appears
much more efficient than that, too.
Their Stricks Halo chip, which launched
last year, however, was a big leap as
you can see in pink on the graph. Where
people might prefer Panther Lake is its
lower power draw, which means it will be
found in thinner and lighter laptops.
Comparing the 16 core X9 to an 8 core
Lunar Lake, it has the same power draw
while delivering 60% more performance.
This is fantastic. This doesn't surprise
us though, as higher core count chips
tend to be more efficient. We're not
sure the 8 core Panther Lake versions
will maintain this efficiency, but we'll
get those numbers to you as soon as
possible. Rounding out this graph,
Apple's M510 core is still more
efficient and the M4 Pro 14 core is even
more impressive. Same hypothesis, the 14
core M4 Pro has more cores. So, we
believe that's one of the key reasons.
One of the benefits of better efficiency
is usually lower CPU temps and less
resulting heat and fan noise, which
holds partially true in the Duo's
highest performance mode. Its CPU temps
stay very reasonable under 90Â° C on
average. internal CPU temps is more
dependent on each laptop's specific
cooling solution, so this may change on
other models. Also, Josh wanted me to
mention the MacBook Pro getting very hot
here is not as bad as it seems. Compared
to Windows manufacturers, Apple keeps
their devices close to silent and lets
them run hotter as a trade-off. He uses
Mac's fan control on his to up the fan
speed a little. Still inaudible to him,
but it keeps his cooler. He hates that
Apple makes him do this, but it does
work. Regarding heat you feel during
performance tasks, Panther Lake looks
promising, but the Duo is a bit of a
unique device. There is an additional
layer between the components and the
keyboard than a normal laptop has since
the keyboard is detachable and sits on
top of the second screen, so keep that
in mind. The Flow also has a detachable
keyboard, but it doesn't have any
components underneath it, so its
keyboard temps are irrelevant. Looking
at fan noise, the Duo is on the upper
end, but this doesn't tell the full
story. We also test its different
performance modes, and balanced is a
much more reasonable option here. It
performs 13% worse, sure, but we'd still
recommend balanced since it maintains
most of the performance. The fan noise
is nearly dead silent. 42 dB is low
enough that I have to turn off our AC,
and my door has to be shut to actually
read it properly. Ambient volume in my
room is about 39. So, this was truly
quiet for the performance it was
getting. In your average room, it's
completely silent in its lowest mode.
After looking at this, we can see why
manufacturers like Dell might be
limiting the average TDP to 35 W in
their XPS 16. They probably decided the
performance was good enough for most
people and they wanted to minimize
distractions like fan noise. Anyway,
this was about what we expected to see
for CPU tasks. We were promised on par
with the older AeroLake H with Lunar
Lake power draws and that appears to be
true. This is positive. But this chip
honestly blew us away in GPU tasks. For
example, in Time Spy, it lands between
the lower wattage 4050 in the MSI Thin
and the mid wattage 50/50 in the LG
Graham. Very impressive. What it also
does well here is CPU performance, and
this is likely due to its efficiency.
You'll notice the Flow's integrated GPU
performs the best here, but it falls
behind the Duo in terms of CPU
performance even though it was beating
it earlier. This is likely because the
Flow pulls power away from its CPU cores
to give to the GPU cores instead. Where
the Panther Lake CPU is performing very
well at low wattage. Continuing on GPU
performance, we were also very impressed
with the addition of ray tracing cores
in the ARC B390. It makes it pull ahead
of the thin again and compete with the
50/50 in the Graham. Not to mention,
it's an insane 86% uplift from Aerrowake
H. Looking at Steel Nomad Light, which
is a cross-platform 1440p benchmark that
the Max can also run, it actually beats
the M5 here by a bit. The dedicated GPUs
and higherend chips keep their lead, but
this is once again a massive improvement
over the integrated graphics in prior
chips. When gaming at full HD resolution
and high settings, which is what we test
on weaker hardware like iGPUs, the ARC
B390 holds its own against low-end
dedicated GPUs being fed less wattage
like you see in the MSI Thin. It also
gets more than 60 FPS, which is
certainly playable for a AAA title. Not
to mention, it's absolutely crushing the
integrated GPUs in both of its
predecessors, Lunar Lake and Aerolake H.
Moving over to Forza, the story is
similar. It gets over 100 FPS, while
Intel's older iGPUs are only hitting 60.
It's getting beat by dedicated GPUs, but
it's still doing better than most
integrated ones currently available. In
Marvel Rivals, it does okay. This is a
newer benchmark for us, so we don't have
it run on everything yet, but we see it
keeps its 1% lows above 30 FPS in medium
settings, which is more than we can say
for Arow Lake H. This is a more
demanding game with lots of fight
scenes. So, if you're playing
competitively, you'll need to lower your
settings. Now, Intel would be
disappointed if we didn't mention that
these chips offer multi-frame
generation, which is a first. Other than
Nvidia last year, XSS technology has
improved to allow for three frames to be
added for each real frame. [snorts]
Gamers go back and forth on whether this
feature actually leads to a better
gaming experience, but if you want more
frames, FPS and Cyberpunk does shoot up
by 82%. 1% lows don't seem to improve,
though, so keep that in mind. This is
unfortunate as most people would prefer
to see an improvement to 1% lows than
average FPS. This lack of scaling of 1%
lows with frame gen on also happens on
some Nvidia laptops. Using gaming
results as our marker, we have another
efficiency graph for you. This is a
newer graph for us, but what I did here
is measure the frames per second in the
Cyberpunk benchmark. I then plotted it
against the average GPU power draw
during this test to get the same
performance as a dedicated Nvidia RTX
4050 in this game around 65 FPS. The
B390 draws 33% less wattage. It also
draws 55% less power than an RTX 5050.
This is super cool to see. It seems like
Intel is much more efficient than
Nvidia. When drawing similar wattage to
the M5's 10 core GPU, it gets 31% more
frames per second, which is also very
good. Intel beating Apple is crazy.
Stricks Halo chips unfortunately do not
separate their CPU and GPU wattage in
our measuring tools. So we couldn't add
AMD's integrated Radeon 8060S to this
graph for comparison. As a whole, that
chip was showing around 61 watts total
during Cyberpunk. So we are doubtful
that the GPU cores are pulling less than
half of that. This leaves Panther Lake
in the lead here in terms of FPS per
watt. By the way, Cyberpunk doesn't hit
the GPU as hard as Forza. We have a
video about why we use Forza for most of
our testing, which I'll link below. We
didn't use Forza here because then we
couldn't compare to the MacBooks if we
did. Again, power efficiency leads to
less annoyances. Gaming in balanced mode
was a treat. It stayed quiet, didn't get
too warm. The 100 FPS number in Forza
from earlier was actually from the Duo's
balanced mode because it does better in
that mode, probably because it gives its
GPU more wattage. Here's the breakdown
for each performance mode. The Duo can
get up to 54 dB if you're putting it in
its highest mode, but we don't see the
point. As we said earlier, measuring the
heat on the keyboard is a bit weird with
the Duo, but Josh even said the little
slim 7i Ultra at CES also didn't get hot
while gaming with its full wattage X9
processor. Other compact 14-in laptops
with dedicated GPUs, like the Zephris
G14, can get insanely hot. So, we are
hopeful these thin and lights will keep
their cool. For AI, we did a quick LM
Studio test to see how it does with the
standard wolf goat cabbage question.
This is using a 14 billion parameter
model, and we use the same seed. It does
a little worse than the M5, but better
than the LOQ with the 50/50, which
weirdly seems to struggle with this
test. It also does better than Aerrow
Lake and Lunar Lake. Now, we of course
had to see how well it performed for
creators. We'll start with video editing
benchmarks like Premiere Pro and Da
Vinci Resolve. In Premiere Pro, the Arc
B390 GPU seems to do well, much better
than most integrated GPUs, and it's not
far behind the M5 chip. This means less
complex projects like ours are viable to
edit. It's a good step forward from the
older Lunar Lake and Aerake laptops
without a dedicated GPU, but it's
certainly not competing with most
dedicated GPUs or higherend MacBook
Pros. You can see that specifically when
you export the project. Time is money
for professional creators like us. So,
we still don't think these are at that
level yet. In Da Vinci Resolve, it falls
behind the competition a bit, but it's
still 46% better than Aerake H, which is
a nice bump. This is somewhere the
MacBooks excel in the Flow with Stricks
Halo stays near the top as well. We also
test 3D rendering in Blender where the
Duo did very well. It beat the Flow and
even one of our gaming laptops with a
higher wattage 4050. It didn't beat the
Max, but hey, there's a reason they're
the go-to for creatives. It's still cool
to see Intel improving so much here.
Now, another place we were very
impressed to see Intel do well was in
battery testing. This goes for both
performance tasks on battery and also
battery duration for light tasks. The
Duo is able to maintain full performance
in Cinebench when unplugged. This is
somewhere the Flow falters. This is also
something Macs do very well, and
although Windows manufacturers have
gotten better about it in recent years,
it's still nice to see every time it
comes up. When I saw this, my immediate
question was whether or not it could
still game on battery since most gaming
laptops nuke their performance. Nvidia
graphics cards just aren't fed full
wattage unplugged. So, good news, the
Duo maintain full performance in gaming,
getting around the same FPS numbers in
Forza. This gets it very close to both
the Grahams RTX 5050 and the Flowzy 13
because they both see drops in
performance when unplugged. A drop of
around 21% and 28% respectively. The Duo
even has more stable 1% lows, which
makes Panther Lake look pretty good. As
far as battery life for lighter tasks
goes, like office work, the Duo actually
beats our M5 MacBook Pro. Let me say
that again. The Duo actually beats our
M5 MacBook Pro. Intel deserves a round
of applause. The Duo's 99Wh battery is
of course a major contributing factor,
but this is still impressive. Just to
even the score, we did normalize our
battery results as if each laptop had a
70Wh battery. The Duo then came in
second, but that's still a good result.
Now, we didn't have time in this video
to test battery life while gaming, but
let us know with a comment below if you
want us to do that. Now, I'm going to
let Josh close us out. All right, as you
can see, this is a big step forward for
Intel. I kind of think this is Intel's
M1 moment. The chips itself not as huge
a leap forward as that one was. But
they're still such an improvement. And
the laptops with them, guys, are also
just so strong that I think people who
buy them, they're going to hold onto
their laptop a really long time, guys.
There are still people who bought one of
those original MacBook Airs with M1 way
back in 2020, and they're still very
good today. [snorts] Now, comparing
these laptops to Apple's current
MacBooks, we do need to be careful which
Apple MacBooks we compare them to. I saw
this article saying the Yoga Slim 7i
Ultra is a MacBook Air killer. Guys,
this is absolutely not a fair
comparison. It's just pure clickbait.
Laptops with this X9 chip, they're
probably going to range around $1,500
to well over 2,000. These will compete
with Apple's MacBook Pro range,
including the models with their
higherend Pro chips. As we've shown you,
Panther Lake, it does compete very well
with a base M5 chip, but it doesn't do
that well vers chip. That being said,
Intel laptops of course have many other
factors that make them better than a
MacBook. Broader application
compatibility, especially in games,
diverse form factors, bells and whistles
like dual screens, touchcreens, and
two-in-1 capabilities. As a whole, I
think these new Panther Lake laptops
will be very competitive with Apple's
range. Now, compared to laptops with
Qualcomm's X2, we still have a lot of
testing to do here. My gut is this.
Qualcomm is kind of giving you more of
what you don't need from their chips,
CPU performance, but they aren't solving
enough of what you do need, broader
application compatibility, although they
are improving there. I feel Qualcomm is
still going to be relegated to competing
based on price and value. Now, compared
with AMD, which is probably Intel's
biggest competitor, AMD bit of a mess
right now. their stricks Halo processor,
which is really good, just isn't
available in many laptops. Then their
mainstream Gorgon Point chips, they're
basically a rebrand of the chips they
released in 2024. Back then, those chips
were really far ahead. But now, Intel
has just caught up. In fact, because of
Intel's GPU, they're solidly ahead. If
the same laptop had the choice of a
Panther Lake X chip or a Gorgon.1, that
AMD laptop, it really needs to be around
$400 cheaper. Well guys, what do you
think? Will you be buying one of these
new Panther Lake laptops? And if you do,
you know what I'm going to say. You have
to check out our website, best laptop
dodges. Over there, we are demystifying
laptop shopping. We show you the top
laptops for each type of buyer. You can
even combine use cases together and we
track prices right across retailers so
you know who's offering the best deal.
Well, today it was all about the X9
chip, which was the embargo for today.
Over the next couple of weeks, we'll be
releasing a ton more videos. We'll be
reviewing all the Panther Lake laptops,
of course, and we'll be testing the
other Panther Lake chips. So, get
subscribed with the notification bell on
because you'll want to be the first to
know. On behalf of all of us here, have
a great rest of your day and we will
catch you later.
